etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Charles Cornwallis (c1555–1629), courtier and diplomat. From dis- + advise

definitions: To advise (a person) against a course or action, undertaking, etc.; to discourage from doing something; to advise not to do something. Now somewhat rare.
To advise against (a course of action, undertaking, etc.); to recommend (something) should not be done.
